ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A broad understanding of genetics, and the ways in which it overlaps with biology (and evolution) and society at large!
The class helped strengthen knowledge I already had in pop gen and supplied new info for quantitative genetics. Both will be useful for me as I continue to learn how to address scientific questions!
This class helped me gain better insight on concepts and methods of analysis in quantitative and population genetics that I had read about in papers but didn't completely understand.
I learned a lot about both quantitative and population genetics, and how to calculate and interpret different population genetics statistics.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I loved this course! As a student who has never taken a real genetics course, I found it super manageable and easy to engage with. Prof. Coughlan is a great lecturer, and does everything they can to make sure students feel heard and supported!

I really think it was a lot of material to cover in a single semester. I wonder if a semester of quant gen and a semester of pop gen would better serve the material. I often struggled with the wording of questions as I typically could argue one way or another on an answer, but I think that improved as the class progressed.

Going through problems in class was useful and showed how to apply the concepts that we were discussing. I also liked the paper discussions, but they might have benefited from small group discussion instead of the whole class.

I found this course really interesting, and I think that it covered a lot of really useful concepts. Specifically, I really appreciated learning about the different statistics in population genetics because I had seen a lot of them before but didnt have a complete understanding of what they represented until this class.

One thing that I think could be improved is adding more ways to earn partial credit on the exams. Sometimes it was stressful to not be able to show my work, and I would make a small mistake and then lose a lot of points on a question.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I definitely would! Any biology student with any level of experience with genetics could benefit from this course. It wasn't too math-heavy, and Professor Coughlan really places an emphasis on learning and understanding  - not just memorizing formulas or statistics.
Yes! If you want to get a background in genetics without going into the details of the biochemistry, especially if you are interested in evolutionary biology, you should definitely take this course!
